moves.3... Nf6: Threatens the e-pawn. Now, for the gambit.
moves.4. Ng5: Someone threatens Nf7, winning queen or rook.
moves.4... d5: The only way to stop it.
moves.6. Nxf7: Someone takes the pawn. One would think: What? But someone is smart.
moves.7. Qf3+: Checks the king with the queen, now the knight is vulnerable.
moves.7... Ke6: Protects the knight. A risky move. Someone else is not in a good position.
moves.8. Nc3: Threatens the knight, as it is pinned to the king by the bishop.
moves.8... Kd6: ?? Gets out of the pin, but this is a really bad move. Checkmate in 3.
moves.9. Qxd5+: I am plus one and am about to get checkmate.
moves.9... Ke7: King moves to the only possible square.
moves.10. Qf7+: I check the king again, being protected by my bishop. Now, mate in one.
moves.10... Kd6: Moves to the only possible square and…
moves.11. Ne4#: Checkmate! The knight checkmates the king, also blocking his escape square: c5. The queen does the rest. That is a perfect example of why NOT to protect the knight with your king when the Fried liver gambit is being played against you.

gameName: Fried Liver Gambit - SO vs. SOE I
opening: two knights defence (C57), Fegatello attack, Leonhardt variation
